docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: About The Project
docs.text:
Python template with some awesome tools to quickstart any Python project

(back to top)

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: To run this project locally, you will need to install the prerequisites and follow the installation section.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: This Project depends on the following projects. * uv sh pip install --user --upgrade uv

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. Clone the repo sh git clone https://github.com/nullhack/python-project-example cd python-project-example
  2. Install uv sh pip install --user --upgrade uv
  3. Install requirements for development sh uv venv uv pip install '.[dev]'
  4. Run tests sh uv run task test

(back to top)

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Some useful examples of how this project can be used:

  • Install requirements sh uv venv uv pip install '.[dev]'

  • Run tests sh uv run task test

  • Run the project sh uv run task run

  • Generate API documentation sh uv run task doc-html

  • Build a docker image for tests sh docker build --target test -t python_package_example:test docker run -ti --rm python_package_example:test

  • Build a docker image to run the root files only without running any test sh docker build --target prod -t python_package_example:prod docker run -ti --rm python_package_example:prod

For more examples, please refer to the Documentation

(back to top)

(back to top)

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
Any contributions you make are greatly appreciated.

If you have a suggestion that would make this better, please fork the repo and create a pull request. You can also simply open an issue with the tag "enhancement". Don't forget to give the project a star! Thanks again!

  1. Fork the Project
  2. Create your Feature Branch (git checkout -b feature/AmazingFeature)
  3. Commit your Changes (git commit -m 'Add some AmazingFeature')
  4. Push to the Branch (git push origin feature/AmazingFeature)
  5. Open a Pull Request

(back to top)

docs.title: python_module_example
docs.text: Module Docstring.

docs.title: logger module-attribute
docs.text: logger = getLogger('python_module_example')

docs.title: Calculator
docs.text:
Class for simple calculator operations.

Source code in .venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/python_package_example/python_module_example.py 
class Calculator:
    """Class for simple calculator operations."""

    @staticmethod
    def divide(a: float, b: float) -> float:
        """Divide a by b.

        Args:
            a (float): Dividend.
            b (float): Divisor.

        Returns:
            float: The result of the division.

        Raises:
            ZeroDivisionError: if b is 0.
            TypeError: if a or b are not float numbers.

        Examples:
            You can run this function as following.

            >>> Calculator.divide(2,1)
            2.0

        """
        if b == 0:
            raise ZeroDivisionError
        if type(a) not in (float, int) or type(b) not in (float, int):
            raise TypeError
        return a / b

docs.title: divide staticmethod
docs.text:
divide(a, b)

Divide a by b.

Parameters:

  • a (float) –

    Dividend.

  • b (float) –

    Divisor.

Returns:

  • float ( float ) –

    The result of the division.

Raises:

  • ZeroDivisionError –

    if b is 0.

  • TypeError –

    if a or b are not float numbers.

Examples:

You can run this function as following.

>>> Calculator.divide(2,1)
2.0
Source code in .venv/lib/python3.13/site-packages/python_package_example/python_module_example.py 
@staticmethod
def divide(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """Divide a by b.

    Args:
        a (float): Dividend.
        b (float): Divisor.

    Returns:
        float: The result of the division.

    Raises:
        ZeroDivisionError: if b is 0.
        TypeError: if a or b are not float numbers.

    Examples:
        You can run this function as following.

        >>> Calculator.divide(2,1)
        2.0

    """
    if b == 0:
        raise ZeroDivisionError
    if type(a) not in (float, int) or type(b) not in (float, int):
        raise TypeError
    return a / b

docs.title: Feature: divide
docs.text: The user should be able to divide two numbers.

docs.title: Scenario Outline: Divide 'a' by 'b'
docs.text:
Given I have two numbers <a> and <b>

       When I divide <a> by <b>

       Then I should see <output>

       Examples:
       |   a   |   b   | output |
       |  2.0  |  2.0  |  1.0   |
       |  6.0  |  2.0  |  3.0   |
       |  1.0  |  2.0  |  0.5   |
